newsitem.title: USA: Midisoft sanctioned over inflated revenues.
newsitem.headline: Midisoft sanctioned over inflated revenues.

text.p: The Securities and Exchange Commission said Wednesday it sanctioned Midisoft Corp for allegedly inflating its 1994 revenues by 16.3 percent or $811,000.

In an order, the SEC told the Issaquah, Wash.,-based provider of software for sound amd music on personal computers, to "cease and desist" from further violations of federal reporting, books and records and internal accounting regulations.
Midisoft consented to the order without admitting or denying the SEC's findings, the agency said.
The SEC alleged that Midisoft overstatement of its 1994 revenues stemmed from two operations.
First, it recorded revenues on goods that the company did not ship to its customers during the year but held at an off-site storage.
Second, the company under-reported sales returns it received for products shipped during the same year.
The agency said certain officers and employees of the company falsified the company's books and records and knowingly circumvented Midisoft's internal accounting controls.

In a separate order, the SEC said it issued another "cease and desist" order against Calvin Dyer, former chief financial officer of the company for his alleged role in the overstatement of the company's revenues.
Dyer, who agreed to the order without admitting or denying any wrongdoing, allegedly caused the books and records of Midisoft to be falsified and circumvented the company's accounting controls.
In addition, the SEC said Dyer lied to Midisoft's auditors and signed the company's 1994 financial statement with knowledge that the document materially misstated Midisoft's financial results.
